Graphical abstract Hollow structure nanoreactors take advantage of catalyst loading and enhanced activity by shell construction. In this work, functionalized poly(ionic liquid)s (PILs) with hollow spherical structures were synthesized by polymerization- and quaternization-based approaches. These hollow structure PILs (HPILs) could be controllable designed from IL monomer easily, giving HPILs various properties. In the subsequent selective oxidation of cyclohexane, the HPILs acting as nanoreactors could efficiently improve the activity of metal salt catalysts (CoCl2) and displayed adjustable selectivity for cyclohexanone, cyclohexanol (KA) or adipic acid (AA) by different types of HPILs. In kinetic study, it follows first-order reaction kinetics which CoCl2/HPIL-C12 had a lower the activation energy of 29.1 kJ/mol. Importantly, these nanoreactors storing the catalysts could be recovered and reused more than 7 times without significant loss of activity. A theoretical model for the hollow spherical reactor was further established to support the advance of the HPILs reactor, which could also help to predict reaction process in other core-shell catalytic system. Due to controlled substrate transfer and enhanced radical generation in HPILs, the reaction process could be adjusted to enhance the conversion of cyclohexane and selective oxidation to AA. Keywords Poly(ionic liquid)s Hollow sphere Cyclohexane Oxidation Adipic acid 1 Introduction The selective oxidation of hydrocarbons has been an important challenge for chemical academia and industry because partial oxidation of saturated C-H bonds is still difficult to control, causing deep oxidation and poor product selectivity. For example, the selective oxidation of cyclohexane (CH) is of great importance in industrial manufacture as the products adipic acid (AA) are key intermediates for the production of polyamides (e.g., nylon-6 or nylon-66), polyurethanes and polyesters [1]. However, the presence of deep oxidative products such as glutaric acid (GA) and succinic acid (SA) makes this reaction poor selectivity [2]. Because the elementary reaction results in homolysis not only of the desired C-H bonds but also for undesired C-C bonds according to a widely known free radical chain mechanism [3,4]. Moreover, the low oxidation activity of CH by green oxidants such as air or molecular oxygen still restricts its large-scale application [5]. These challenges encourage researchers to develop catalysts with high activity and selectivity for the selective oxidation of CH [6,7]. In contrast, metal salt catalysts often show a higher activity because of the electron structure of metal species optimized by ligands [8,9], and usually take advantage of mass and heat transfer [10], which the real industrial process usually uses soluble cobalt or manganese salt catalysts in the presence of molecular oxygen, however, suffering from hard separation, high cost of ligands and poor reusability [11,12]. Therefore, it is imperative to solve the problems of metal salt catalysts and develop a new catalytic process for the selective oxidation of CH. Hollow structure nanospheres (HSNS) with large internal space and functional shells are attracting wide interest and present great utilitarian value for energy storage [13,14], separation [15], drug delivery [16] and catalysis [17–19]. It is expected to gain high loading of guest species and molecular sieving effects, giving it possible to construct nanoreactors to promote the reaction and improve the selectivity [20]. In particular, HSNS can not only be considered a warehouse to store reactants or catalysts but also enhance mass transport [21], which increases the adsorption of reactants and controls the desorption of products. A concentration gradient across the HSNS can cause the molecular diffusion to migrate spontaneously from regions of high concentration to those of low concentration, making a new catalytic process for the reaction [22]. HSNS of various materials, such as metal oxide [23], metal sulfide [24], MOFs [25] and polymers [26,27] have been structured successfully to confirm the advantage of activity and mass transfer in catalysis. However, the shells of HSNS are usually incompatible with polar or nonpolar substances as a result of different adsorption potentials [28], causing catalysts or reactants that have different polarities to be difficult to synchronously enter the cavity. Therefore, the design of the shell matrix is the key to constructing a nanoreactor in the selective oxidation of CH. Poly(ionic liquid)s (PILs) are chosen here as candidates with great potential to synthesize nanoreactors, in which the structure and properties can be adjusted by tunable IL monomers and polymer backbones. Although PILs have wide applications in different areas (e.g., separation, catalysis, batteries, supercapacitors) [29–31], the controlled synthesis of hollow structure PILs is less explored. PILs have been proven to be talent for electron transfer [32], substrate absorption [30] and oxygen reduction [33], which could favor oxidation reactions. In this case, PIL nanoreactors may effectively transfer active substances and coordinate with metal salt catalysts due to the ionic regions, thus improving the activity of the oxidation reaction and obtaining the reusability of catalysts by storage. In this study, we report a synthesis approach of hollow structure PILs (HPILs), in which HPILs served as nano-reactor and cooperated with metal salt catalysts are performed in selective oxidation of CH. The properties of HPILs could be regulated by IL monomers with different alkyl chains. The crucial point of strategy is that the solvent cage in the nanoreactor can effectively promote the reaction, which is similar to CNTs [34], and the shell of aromatic rings and IL monomers as building blocks facilitate electron transfer between catalysts and reactants. As a result, a nanoreactor strategy efficiently improved the activity and selectivity of AA by different HPILs. HPILs not only act as nanoreactors but also bridge active substances to catalysts. Owing to the ionic part and hydrocarbon part of the nanoreactor, polar or nonpolar substrate transport could be controlled by the designed HPILs. Therefore, this work offers a new method in selective oxidation to achieve high activity and selectivity, especially, can be extended to other catalytic reactions. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Sodium hydroxide (NaOH, AR), styrene (AR), methacrylic acid (MA, AR), potassium peroxodisulfate (KPS, AR), divinyl benzene (DVB, AR), N-vinyl imidazole (VIM, AR), 1-chlorobutane (AR), 1-chlorohexane (AR), 1-chlorododecne (AR), acetonitrile (MeCN) and acetone (DMK) were purchased from Aladdin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd. α-Alenyl sodium sulfonate (AOS, 92%) was purchased from Shandong Usolf Chemical Technology Co. Ltd. 1-Butyl-3-methylimidazolium chloride (BmimCl), 1-Dodecyl-3-methylimidazolium chloride (DmimCl) was purchased from Linzhou Technology & Energy Co. Ltd. Copper oxide (CuO), NaX zeolite (NaX), vanadium pentoxide (V2O5), vanadium phosphorus oxide (VPO) were from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. 2.2 Synthesis of core PS anionic polystyrene microsphere emulsions Specifically, 240 g of deionized water was injected into a three-necked flask. Then, the samples were bubbled with nitrogen for 30 min to remove the water-soluble oxygen in this system. After that, 0.1 g AOS was added to the solution under vigorous stirring conditions. After AOS dissolved, 29.0 mL styrene (the styrene was first washed thoroughly with 1 M NaOH solution and deionized water successively to remove the polymerization inhibitor) and 0.9 mL MA were added to this system. After stirring emulsification for 30 min, the temperature was improved to 70 °C and stirring for 15 min. After that, 30 mL KPS solution (0.5 wt%) was added to the mixture to launch the polymerization reaction of styrene. After stirring for 12 h at 70 °C, the obtained milk-like product was the anionic polystyrene microsphere emulsion. 2.3 Preparation of hollow spheres HPILs Specifically, 5 mL of the as-prepared PS emulsion was added to 32.5 mL deionized water in a flask under stirring conditions. In this state, 1 mL DVB and 1 mL VIM were added into the flask with continuous agitation for 1 h. Then, 6 mL KPS solution (0.5 wt%) was added to this system at 75 °C. After stirring for 24 h at this temperature, the precursor of HPILs was obtained and named HPVIM. Then, excess 1-chlorobutane (1-chlorohexane or 1-chlorododecne) was added to the HPVIM solution (volume ratio = 1:5) under stirring conditions at 70 °C for 24 h to achieve ionization production. Then, the HPILs were obtained by etching the PS core with THF and separated by high-speed centrifugation at 9000 r/min. After washing with deionized water, the white solid was dried at 70 °C for 12 h. 2.4 Characterization Specific surface areas and pore size distributions were investigated by the Brumauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method on ASAP 2460. SEM and TEM tests were performed on SU8020 and JEM-2100F, respectively. FT-IR spectroscopy of all samples was performed on a Shimadzu IRtracer-100 in the wavenumber range from 400 cm−1 to 4000 cm−1. The zeta potential of HPILs was measured by a zeta potential analyzer (Antonpaar, Litesizer™500). The chemical states of Co and N of the catalysts and nanoreactor were determined by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (ESCALAB 250Xi, Thermo Fisher Scientific). Electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectra were recorded by using an EMXplus-9.5/12 instrument from Bruker. Contact angle measurements were carried out on a DSA25 Drop shape analyzer from KRUSS at room temperature and recorded by Advance software. The small-angle X-ray scattering (SAXS) experiment was carried out on NanoinXider SAXS instruments from Xenocs SA, Sassengae, France. This instrument used a GeniX3D Cu ULD integrated beam delivery system to generate highly monochromatic Cu Kα radiation, which consists of a 30 W microfocus X-ray tube and an integrated parabolic multilayer mirror, operating at 50 kV and 0.6 mA. The distance of sample to detector was 938 mm. The data were collected using a Pilatus3 CMOS hybrid pixel detector (Dectris Ltd, Baden, Switzerland). The relevant microscope is based on a set of self-built inverted fluorescence microscopes integrated on a commercially available platform. Samples were excited with 532 nm lasers (Coherent OBISTM) and imaged onto an electron multiplying charge-coupled device (EMCCD) camera (iXon Ultra 888, Andor Technology) through a 100×, 1.30 numerical aperture oil immersion objective (Nikon). The obtained images were analyzed with ImageJ. The prepared particles were dispersed in ethanol (10 μg/mL), 200 μL was added dropwise to the glass slide, deposited for 10 min and dried. Place the glass slide on the platform, first soak the sample with acetonitrile, and then add the Nile Red dye solution (10–5 M) during the imaging process. 2.5 Catalytic procedure of selective oxidation Typically, the catalysts/HPIL catalytic system would be incorporated firstly that 13 mg CoCl2 catalysts and 60 mg HPILs would be mixed in acetonitrile and vacuum dried at 70 °C overnight to remove the solvent. In a typical reaction, CH (2.1 g), catalyst (13 mg), HPIL nanoreactor (40 mg) and solvent were added to a stainless-steel autoclave. The mixture was purged with O2 three times and pressurized to 1.5 MPa with O2. After stirring at 130 °C for 3 h, the autoclave was cooled in an ice bath. The resulting mixture was dissolved in dichloromethane, and chlorobenzene and pimelic acid were added as the internal standard. The small amount of liquid phase was analyzed on a SHIMADZU gas chromatograph (GC-2010 plus) with FID on capillary column HP-1 to quantify the KA oil intermediate according to chlorobenzene. Then, the organic diacid products of AA, GA, and SA were analyzed by a methyl esterification step. The mixture was concentrated by rotary evaporation and transferred into the reactor with 2 mL methanol and 1 mL 98% sulfuric acid at 100 °C for 1 h to ensure esterification. After the reaction, the mixture was evaporated to remove the methanol, while the corresponding esters were collected by dichloromethane in 5 mL DI water. The collected mixture was analyzed by GC-FID to obtain the amount of diacid products according to the internal standard. In recycling experiments, the catalysts with nanoreactors could be easily separated by high-speed centrifugation at 9000 r/min and further washed with ethyl acetate three times to remove the products. The catalysts/nanoreactor dried at 80 °C overnight and were used to perform catalytic experiments following a previous process. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 HPILs nanoreactor preparation and characterization The synthesis procedure of HPILs is illustrated in Fig. 1 . Core PS with an anionic surface was fabricated to adsorb divinyl benzene (DVB) and N-vinyl imidazole (VIM) monomers. After polymerization was performed under KPS, the shell of HPVIM was construed. Then, the shells were modified by adding different chloroalkanes (1-chlorobutane, 1-chlorohexane or 1-chlorododecne) under quaternization. Finally, HPIL nanoreactors were obtained by THF etching after removing the PS core. The formation of HPILs was confirmed by XPS technology [35]. Fig. 2 a shows the XPS spectra of HPILs with different alkyl chains, in which the N 1s spectra of HPILs displayed two peaks at binding energies of 401.0 eV and 399.0 eV attributed to a pair of C-N bonds in the imidazole ring. Before quaternization of imidazolium units, HPVIM showed imidazole peaks for N 1s at 400.4 eV and 398.5 eV. The distinct shift to a higher binding energy of N 1s demonstrated that HPIL was fabricated by quaternization to endow the imidazole group with a positive charge. The structures of HPIL spheres (HPIL-C4, HPIL-C6 and HPIL-C12) were further measured by FT-IR [44]. As shown in Fig. 2b, the peaks ranging from 2800 cm−1 to 3000 cm−1 were attributed to the stretching vibration of C-H on part of the imidazolium cations and backbone. The peak arising at 1452 cm−1 was ascribed to the stretching vibration of C-N in the skeleton of the imidazole ring. The benzene ring torsion of =C-H was located at 698 cm−1. The characteristics of the imidazole and benzene rings indicated that PIL was successfully introduced in hollow spheres by polymerization and quaternization processes. The pore structure of HPILs was measured by N2 adsorption-desorption [26], as shown in Fig. 2c. From the adsorption-desorption isotherm, all HPILs exhibited a type IV curve and H3 hysteresis loop according to the classification of the International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry (Fig. 2c). An adsorption uptake at low relative pressure and a hysteresis loop at high relative pressure demonstrated the existence of micropores and mesopores. In addition, the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface areas of HPIL-C4, HPIL-C6 and HPIL-C12 were 68.0 m2/g, 71.6 m2/g and 29.7 m2/g, respectively. The total pore volume of each HPIL sphere was 0.11 cm3/g, 0.13 cm3/g and 0.04 cm3/g. The pore-size distribution was further calculated by density functional theory (DFT). Micropores below 5 nm were widely spread in HPIL-C4 and HPIL-C6, whereas HPIL-C12 only possessed micropores between 1.3 and 1.7 nm and mesopores at 24 nm. (Fig. S1) These micro/mesopores were mainly produced by the cross-linking areas within the polymeric shells. However, a long alkyl chain could fill these holes and cause a tightened polymer network, explaining the elimination of some micro/mesopores in HPIL-C12. In addition, to confirm the electrostatic interaction transformation of the HPIL nanoreactor, the zeta potentials of PS, HPIL-C4, HPIL-C6 and HPIL-C12 were measured, as shown in Fig. 2d. Obviously, the zeta potential value of the pristine PS core was –32 mV when dispersed in DI water; however, the zeta potential values of HPIL-C4, HPIL-C6 and HPIL-C12 became positive, affording +4.2 mV, +5.2 mV and +15.7 mV, respectively. The negative value of PS was attributed to the benzene and carboxylic groups, and the positive value of the HPIL spheres was due to their cations from IL units. Long alkyl chains from cations could develop the nucleophilicity of IL units, thus adjusting the zeta potential to a larger extent. It suggested that the long alkyl chain could decrease the charge distribution on cation or anion [36]. Thus, it weakened the intermolecular forces between cation and anion to improve the delocalization of anion [37], showing a larger zeta potential value [38]. In addition, the thermal stability of HPILs measured by thermogravimetric analysis (Fig S5). It suggested that the HPILs could be stable below 320 °C under air atmosphere which the longer alkyl chain the higher decomposition temperature of HPILs. The TGA results suggested the nanoreactor could be stable in the catalytic process. The morphology and hollow sphere structure of HPILs were confirmed by SEM and TEM. Core PS, HPIL-C4, HPIL-C6 and HPIL-C12 were studied by SEM, as shown in Fig. 3 . The synthesized anionic PS particles presented uniform spherical morphology with a diameter of 100 nm. The corresponding HPILs of hollow spheres were larger than PS, and HPILs exhibited a relatively uniform nanosphere feature with diameters of 140–178 nm. The spheres of HPILs often showed a collapsed and rough surface due to the hollow structure and IL units. However, plump, regular and smaller spheres of HPVIM could be found before quaternization and etching (Fig. S2). This result indicated that the soft materials of HPILs were synthesized based on PS-core spheres and that the length of the alkyl chain of the cation did not significantly change the morphology and size of the HPIL spheres. These hollow microspheres of HPILs were observed and confirmed by TEM. As shown in Fig. 4 , HPIL-C4, HPIL-C6 and HPIL-C12 showed a hollow-shell structure with a clear boundary, and the cavity was consistent with the PS size. The size distribution of the shell was 18–38 nm in HPIL-C4, while the shells of HPIL-C6 and HPIL-C12 were 18–35 nm. All these results confirmed the successful preparation of the HPIL nanoreactor with a hollow structure. The surface charge diversity demonstrated that the properties of the HPIL shell should be different. In the measurement of small-angle X-ray scattering (SAXS), the microspheres of HPIL hollow spheres and the average core-shell size with the corresponding scattering length density (SLD) of the particle were characterized and calculated [39]. Fig. 5 a shows the SAXS curves of HPIL-C4, HPIL-C6 and HPIL-C12 in water at 298.2 K. It’s clearly that the intensity of the HPILs decreased as the length of the alkyl chain increased under the same scattering wavevector (q) because the electron density decreased as the alkyl chain grew, further showing a lower SLD (Fig. 5a). The minimum of the scattering curve in three HPILs was same, indicating that the size of the hollow spheres was similar, which was consistent with the SEM and TEM results. The fitting curves all agreed well with the experimental data of each HPIL sphere by a core-shell model. According to the fitting data, SLD as a function of distance from the center of HPILs was calculated by SASview software (Fig. 5b). The SLD profiles provided information on the average size of the core-shell and the corresponding SLD. The particle sizes of the HPIL spheres were similar, and the average radius of HPIL-C4, C6 and C12 were 657 Å, 660 Å and 656 Å, respectively. However, the thickness and SLD of shells were different in each PIL hollow sphere, and HPIL-C12 had a thinner shell (339 Å) than HPIL-C4 (360 Å) and HPIL-C6 (369 Å). It is compared with the TEM and SEM results. This is reasonable because the HPILs were dispersed in water, and the shell could be swelled due to absorption from the IL unit, causing a smaller hollow and larger shell. The long alkyl chain of HPIL-C12 with more hydrophobic ability explained the thinner shell. In these core-shell models, the average SLD of each HPIL sphere decreased from the inside out, meaning a decreasing electron density. In the hollow structure, the inner layer of HPILs providing more ions gave a high SLD in the core, suggesting a gradient concentration of IL units. After the experimental data were reconstructed by DENSS calculation [40], 3D electron density maps were obtained to support the trend of IL concentration in the shell. As shown in Fig. 5c, the electron density of HPIL-C4 particles decreased from inner to outer colored red to blue, which supported the SLD calculation. The results indicated that IL was enriched in the interior, suggesting a gradient shell structure. 3.2 Effect of substrate transfer in HPILs Fluorescence tests were used to study the migration of reactants in nanoreactors or metal salts. Nile red was used as a probe to visualize this process, which could reveal important information on reactant transport. First, the dispersed nanoreactor HPIL-C12 was soaked in MeCN (Fig. 6 a). After cyclohexane with the probe was introduced, the specific fluorescent signal from the probe was directed at fluorescein emission 635 nm (Fig. 6b), indicating that the fluorescence molecules crossed the nanoreactor interface and entered the sphere. However, no signal was observed in CoCl2 after the reactant was added (Fig. 6c-d). It should be noted that CH was not soluble in MeCN, suggesting an obstructed transport of reactants on metal salts in MeCN solvent. The results showed the advantage of reactant transfer in the nanoreactor under MeCN solvent. In parallel, nanoreactors or salts were dried to remove solvent. After the addition of cyclohexane with probes, fluorescence could strongly appear on the nanoreactor (Fig. 6e-f), and metal salts with little signal could be found (Fig. 6j-h). These experiments suggested that the hollow structure and HPIL shell of the nanoreactor enhanced the transport of reactants across the polymer interface. The adsorption of CH in HPILs was also confirmed in water by SAXS detection. As shown in Fig. 7 , an obvious change could be found after CH was added to the HPIL/water system in the SAXS spectra. The intensity of the HPILs shifted to a smaller scattering wavevector (q) because the HPILs could strongly adsorb the CH in the shell and cavity, which decreased the electron density of the HPILs. The minimum scattering curve of HPILs did not move, suggesting that the HPILs could maintain their structure and morphology in the presence of CH. Although all HPILs shifted by CH, the curve of HPIL-C12 moved the most, suggesting that HPIL-C12 could transfer or obtain CH efficiency. The contact angles of water, reactant and product were measured on HPILs to explore the reaction process. The water contact angles of HPIL-C4, HPIL-C6 and HPIL-C12 were 62°, 90° and 108° respectively, indicating that the length of the alkyl chain could cause a significant change in the hydrophilic properties of the nanoreactor (Fig. 8 a). Long alkyl chains on IL units provided more hydrophobicity of HPIL. Due to the hollow structure of the particles, the water diffused into the cavity as a result of the channel from the ionic shell of the HPIL, causing a sharp decrease in the water contact angle in 5 s (Fig. S3). The contact angles of the reactant (CH) were also tested, and low angles could be found on HPIL-C4, HPIL-C6 and HPIL-C12 (Fig. 8b). This means that the oil wettability of the HPIL surface could enhance reactant transfer in the shell and that CH could be infiltrated quickly in 3 s (Fig. S3). The KA oil (50 % K and 50% A in mole) contact angles were not same for the different nanoreactors, and HPIL-C4 had the lowest contact angle of about 20°. As the branch chain of the IL units became long, the contact angles of HPIL-C6 and HPIL-C12 changed to 25° and 38° as a result of the weak polarity of the shell (Fig. 8c). 3.3 Catalytic performance in HPILs nanoreactor and kinetics study In the oxidation of CH, activity and various oxidative products of cyclohexanone (K), cyclohexanol (A), glutaric acid (GA), succinic acid (SA) and adipic acid (AA) are difficult to control in academic and industry. Transition metal salts of Co, have been widely used in this reaction to improve the activity and selectivity [2,36]. The functions of different HPILs nanoreactor were examined in the oxidation of cyclohexane to the main product (KA oil, AA and others of SA and GA). As shown in Table 1 , pure CoCl2 gave traces of conversion (entry 1), while the only HPILs nanoreactor could hardly tiger the reaction (entry 2–3). Even with the addition of catalysts, it’s difficult to induce the reaction in HPILs with PS-core inside. However, the production could be achieved in the hollow structure nanoreactor with CoCl2 catalysts (entries 5–7), it achieved 3.5%, 3.2% and 7.8% conversion of CH corresponding to HPIL-C4, HPIL-C6 and HPIL-C12. It showed the catalysts could obtained a higher conversion and selectivity of AA in HPIL-C12 nanoreactor may attributed to the advantage of the reactant transfer. After DMK solvent addition, CoCl2 realized 8.2% conversion with 71.7% selectivity of KA [41]. The HPILs with PS-core inside still didn’t have an improving performance in solvent, affording 7.3% conversion and 73.8% KA selectivity (entry 9). The ILs with butyl and dodecyl alkane in branch were also measured with CoCl2 to identify the effect of IL units in HPILs (entries 10–11). It showed that CoCl2/ILs didn’t afford an enhanced. properties, whereas it could regulate selectivity of AA that 25.8% and 35.6% for CoCl2/BmimCl and CoCl2/DmimCl. Because the ILs could attenuate the transfer of cyclohexane and enhance the transport of polar products due to their nature of charge and hydrogen bond interaction. Surprisingly, the co-presence of HPILs nanoreactor efficiently improved the activity and selectivity. In CoCl2/HPIL-C4, CH could be converted with an increased conversion (12.1%) and AA selectivity (23.2%) (entry 12). When HPIL-C12 with a long alkyl chain in IL monomer was used, it could efficiently improve catalytic activity of CoCl2 from 8.2% conversion to 19.8% conversion and the selectivity of AA could reach to 42.2% (entry 13). After prolonged time for 3 h, excellent performance of CoCl2 could be found in HPILs that conversion could be above 26.4% (entries 14–16), and the CoCl2/HPIL-C12 achieved the highest AA selectivity for 72.7%. Although the amount of solvent was reduced, the catalyst still had high activity with 24.4% conversion in 1 mL DMK solvent for 1 h (entry 17). To compared with other types of catalysts, metal oxide, zeolite or electronic promotor were used in this reaction. CuO and NaX zeolite had trace conversion in oxidation of CH, while V2O5 could reach 7.1% conversion and 15.5% AA selectivity (entry 20). VPO catalysts, which were widely used in oxidation of alkane [42], had a lower activity that afford 4.2% conversion and 20.5% AA selectivity (entry 21). NHPI generating radical during the reaction gave 6.3% conversion under the same condition. The results suggested that CoCl2/HPIL-C12 had a higher catalytic performance compared with other catalytic systems. Moreover, the catalytic performance of CoCl2, CoCl2/DmimCl and CoCl2/HPIL-C12 were compared at the same condition within 50 min (Fig. 9 a). Clearly, CoCl2 catalysts could take an improvement of activity in HPIL-C12 nanoreactor compared with pure CoCl2 or in DmimCl (Fig. 9a). In the production distribution, Fig. 9b showed higher AA selectivity in HPIL-C12 and DmimCl after 20 min running, which pure CoCl2 had a higher KA selectivity. The kinetic order with respect to the time was fitted by first-order kinetic with a linear increase presenting in Fig. 9c. According to first-order reaction kinetics, the reaction rate constant of CoCl2, CoCl2/DmimCl and CoCl2/HPIL-C12 could be calculated, that 0.46 × 10−3 min−1, 0.65 × 10−3 min−1 and 2.85 × 10−3 min−1 respectively. The results confirmed the HPIL-C12 could significantly improve activity and show a higher AA selectivity. To further explore the kinetic of CoCl2/DmimCl and CoCl2/HPIL-C12, kinetic parameters were determined by different temperature in various times (Fig. 9d, 9e). Both catalytic systems were good fitting with first-order reaction. The activation energies (Ea) of CoCl2/DmimCl and CoCl2/HPIL-C12 were calculated by Arrhenius function (Fig. 9f), that CoCl2/HPIL-C12 (29.1 kJ/mol) had a lower activation energy than CoCl2/DmimCl (46.5 kJ/mol). The above results suggested that HPIL nanoreactor with hollow structure could enhance the activity and regulate the selectivity of the product. The influence of reactant concentration on the activity were investigated at the condition of 25 mmol CH, 130 °C, 1.5 MPa O2 and various amount of DMK for 1 h with same catalysts concentration. As shown in Fig. 10 a, the catalytic behaviours were different in pure CoCl2 and CoCl2/HPIL-C12. With decreasing amount of DMK solvent, high concentration of CH accelerated the process of oxidation reaction in CoCl2/HPIL-C12, whereas less DMK solvent hindered the mass transfer in CoCl2 showing a decreasing activity in high concentration of reactant. It demonstrated the superiority of HPIL in mass transfer of reactant. However, it’s not the more HPILs the higher activity. In Fig. 10b, the addition of HPILs had an optimum point at mass concentration of 1.38%, that achieving a high conversion of 24.4% in 1 h. The selectivity was also regulated by the amount of HPIL-C12. The selectivity of AA increased along with the HPIL-C12 adding, although the conversion was decreasing. The results shown CoCl2/HPIL-C12 had a high activity and selectivity of AA. Most importantly, these HPIL nanoreactors gave CoCl2 catalyst reusability because the PIL shell could adsorb and complex the metal species [30,43], and the hollow structure of the HPILs could store the catalysts. Fig. 10c shows that CoCl2/HPIL-C12 maintained a high conversion of CH (above 21%) in the catalytic activity during 7 recycles. And the mass fraction of Co from CoCl2/HPIL-C12 was slightly decreased from 13.6% to 11.5% quantified by ICP-OES after 7 recycles. 3.4 Storage and enhanced catalysis by HPILs nanoreactor To confirm the role of the nanoreactor in storing catalysts, the internal structure of metal salts within the HPIL nanoreactor was characterized by TEM before and after the reaction. As shown in Fig. 11 a-b, CoCl2 could be stored in HPILs successfully before the reaction, and metal salt particles were widely spread in the cavity. Because of the coordination of Co with the IL monomer, the distribution of CoCl2 was concentrated in the inner layer (Fig. 11b), which was similar to the 3D electron density map from the SAXS data (Fig. 5c), confirming the gradient concentration of ILs among the HPIL shells. Even after the reaction, Co catalysts could still be maintained in the nanoreactor, and HPILs retained the hollow structure to confirm the stability of the nanoreactor in the reaction, as shown in Fig. 11c-d. Moreover, the elements N, Co and C of CoCl2/HPIL-C12 after reaction can be clearly observed from the TEM elemental analysis (Fig. 11 e-l). The elemental mapping images of N and C demonstrated that IL monomers were successfully introduced into HPILs and showed the stability of the chemical structure during the reaction (Fig. 11f, h). The Co elemental map indicates that the encapsulated CoCl2 not only exists in the cavity but is also distributed among the shells of the HPILs (Fig. 11g). To further prove the Co distribution, images of HPILs without Co particles in the cavity were also chosen and explored by elemental mapping images after reaction (Fig. 11i-l). Beside the C and N elements in HPILs, Co was dispersed in the shell to demonstrate that the HPILs could lock the catalysts, and revealed the reaction could be occurred in the shell. The catalysts combined with HPIL-C12 were measured by XPS to check the changes in the surface characteristics of the samples before and after the reaction (Fig. 12 ). The Co 2p XPS spectrum showed four peaks corresponding to Co 2p1/2 (796.8 eV) and Co 2p3/2 (781.0 eV) due to spin-orbit coupling, as well as their satellite bands. The separated binding energy between 2p1/2 and Co 2p3/2 was 15.2 eV, suggesting a high-spin Co2+ state [44]. According to a previous work [45], the Co 2p3/2 peak could be deconvoluted into two components: fully coordinated cobalt at 782.5 eV and unsaturated cobalt species at 780.6 eV. This demonstrated that Co could coordinate in PIL units. It is worth noting that the Co state would not be changed after the reaction, which means that the catalysts could be stable in the HPIL nanoreactor during the reaction. The N 1 s spectra of HPIL-C12 and CoCl2/HPIL-C12 before and after the reaction are presented in Fig. 12b. The peaks of HPIL-C12 in N 1 s were divided into quaternary N (401.2 eV) and imidazole N (399.2 eV) from the cation ring. However, the shape of the N 1 s spectrum was different in CoCl2/HPIL-C12, suggesting that a new peak of N coordinated with Co (N-Co) was located at 400.1 eV [46]. A slight shift of quaternary N from 401.2 eV to 401.4 eV was caused by a changing charge distribution of the imidazole ring under CoCl2 coordination. Furthermore, the N 1 s peaks of the CoCl2/HPIL-C12 samples after reaction agreed with those of the fresh sample, confirming the stability of CoCl2/HPIL-C12 and the interaction between the catalyst and nanoreactor. To further explore the effect of the nanoreactor, CoCl2/HPIL-C12 was measured by EPR to detect the radicals (Fig. 13 ). The EPR spectrum of Co(II) has a low single at room temperature because the spin lattice relaxation time was extremely short for octahedral coordination of Co(II). A broad line centered at g = 2.06 is according to a random distribution from octahedral symmetry, which could also be found in the CoCl2/HPIL-C12 complex. Interestingly, the electron structure could be regulated by HPILs, and EPR spectroscopy of CoCl2/HPIL-C12 powder gave an isotropic signal with g = 2.003 at room temperature, in which radicals in cobalt complexes with ligands were often observed [47,48]. As the promoter of free radicals in HPILs, the reaction could be easily triggered to achieve a higher activity. Even with reused catalysts in HPILs, isotropic signals of g = 2.003 still existed, suggesting high activity in sustainable usage. In addition, the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface areas of HPIL-C12 decreased to 6.0 m2/g, and the total pore volume decreased to 0.01 cm3/g after reaction because of the loading of the metal salts filling the hole of polymer (Fig. S4). 3.5 Theoretical investigation of reaction process in HPILs The above results confirmed that the HPIL nanoreactor with controlled transport of substrate could store catalysts promoting radical generation to enhance the activity in selective oxidation of CH. The cavity of HPILs gave room for catalysts. If the reaction occurred in a limited range, a high concentration of catalysts could accelerate the reaction. In order to further understand the reasons for the enhanced catalysis efficiency in HPILs, the kinetic equation inside a spherical reactor was established by assuming spherical symmetry around each particle, describing the localized reactions occurring inside. A general reaction, A → k A B considering input, output and reaction consumption of A, was writing below: (1) I n p u t o f A : D H A 4 π r + d r 2 d dr c A + d c A dr d r (2) O u t p u t o f A : D H A 4 π r 2 d c A dr (3) R e a c t i o n c o n s u m p t i o n : 4 π r 2 d r ( k A c A ) where c A denoted the concentrations of reactants, and r represents the radial distance from the center of the spherical particle. The parameters D H A were the diffusion coefficients of A in HPILs, where k A are the rate constants of the reactions. Under steady state conditions, input – output = reaction consumption. After we define z = r / R which R is the radium of the HPILs, the following equation describe the mass balance inside the HPIL: (4) d 2 c A d z 2 + 2 z d c A dz = R 2 D H A ( k A c A ) Now, an equation of distance and concentration was obtained, which the distribution of A in HPILs could be achieved by solving this equation. Continually, Thiele modulus was defined as φ H = R 3 k A D H A , and defined ω A = c A z , both substituted the above equation (4). Therefore, we got a simplified equation (derivative process in SI): (5) d 2 ω A d z 2 = ( 3 φ H ) 2 c A z = ( 3 φ H ) 2 ω By solving this equation with the boundary condition (derivative process in SI), concentration profiles of reactant in the radial direction could be obtained: (6) c A = c AS z sinh 3 φ H z sinh 3 φ H where, c AS was the concentration of reactant on the surface of spherical particles. Now at steady-state, the fluxes of A entering and leaving the interface of hollow-shell and shell-surrounding had to be equal (assumed the diffusion coefficients of A are the same in cavity and surrounding). In that case: (7) S u r r o u n d i n g i n t e r f a c e : D H A d c AS dr = D S A d c S dr (8) C a v i t y i n t e r f a c e : D S A d c AC dr = D H A d c AI dr where c S was the surrounding concentration of A, c AI was the concentration of inlayer of the shell and c AC was concentration of interface on cavity side. Similarly, the production concentration of B could also be calculated by the kinetic equation. In the tandem reaction, A → k A B → k B C , production of B accumulated by the conversion of A was consumed in further reaction to C. Thus, equation (4) could be transformed by adding the generation of B to describe the describe the mass balance of B (defined - r A + r B = - k c B ): (9) d 2 c B d z 2 + 2 z d c B dz = - R 2 D H B kc B where D H B was the diffusion coefficients of B in HPILs, and c B denoted the concentrations of B. Following derivative process above, the concentration profiles of production in the radial direction could be obtained by solving the equation (9) (derivative process of in SI): (10) c B = c SB s i n ( 3 φ B z ) z sin 3 φ B Same with equation (7), (8), fluxes of B entering and leaving the interface of hollow-shell and shell-surrounding had to be equal at steady-state: (11) S u r r o u n d i n g i n t e r f a c e : D H B d c AS dr = D S B d c S dr (12) C a v i t y i n t e r f a c e : D S B d c BC dr = D H B d c BI dr Using equations sets of (6), (7), (8) and (10), (11), (12), the concentration profiles of reactant A and product B along the radial distance can finally be evaluated by diffusion, core-shell structure, reaction rate constants and the concentration of A, B in the solvent. As shown in Fig. 14 a, the high concentration of CH began to enter the nanoreactor, and it diffused and reacted to consumed CH in the shell. After entering the cavity, CH could convert to KA further. KA oil which was the intermediate products could be oxidated to AA. It aggregated and consumed in the cavity, meanwhile, it diffused and reacted in the shell and finally to the external environment. The concentration profiles of pure catalysts (assumed as spherical particles) were firstly plotted in Fig. 14b, compared with the HPIL that of core inside. It shown that the concentration of reactant was maximum at the particle interface. The catalysts with a bad transfer for reactant had a higher concentration on the surface layer, but decreasing sharply in short distance. The HPILs (core inside) with high diffusion of reactant fast transfer the reactant into the particle showing a lower concentration. Even though the concentration of reactant in HPILs (with-core) was higher than that of pure catalysts in the core, it didn’t show the advantage in catalysis. However, if the core was removed from HPILs to fabricate a cavity, the concentration profile would be changed distinctly. As shown in Fig. 14c, the concentration of CH could be enlarged in the cavity, where is the place storing catalysts to initiated the reaction. As the diffusion of the reactant enlarging, an increasing amount of reactant could be involved in the reaction. As the reaction is the first-order reaction, it could be improved through increasing CH concentration in the cavity, supporting excellent catalytic performance in CoCl2/HPIL-C12. The results confirmed that enhanced transfer for reactant could improve the activity of the catalysts. In the intermediate products (KA) profile (Fig. 14d), the concentration decreased from the cavity to the surrounding, while the shell had a higher concentration of the production. If the diffusion of KA was lower, obviously, the concentration could be increasing in the cavity to enhance the deeper oxidation of KA explaining a higher AA selectivity in CoCl2/HPIL-C12. The derived profiles are helpful to understand the transfer factor for the reaction inside HPILs. In catalytic conversion, the presence of HPILs adjusted the electron structure of metal catalysts to promote the generation and transfer of radicals. In addition, the transfer of reactant could be enhanced by different HPILs, giving a high concentration in the batch. Consequently, catalysis efficiency was great enhanced. After the CH converted to KA, the nanoreactor with a short alkyl chain (HPIL-C4) allowed KA to pass through freely, while HPIL-C12 had a relatively low transfer for KA to further encourage KA conversion to AA. According to the free radical chain mechanism, the charge from the IL monomer and the aromatic ring from the block could facilitate electron and active species transfer to promote the oxidation reaction. In this catalytic process, HPILs could effectively improve the activity of traditional catalysts and regulate the selectivity of AA. 4 Conclusions Hollow structure poly(ionic liquid)s (HPILs) acting as nanoreactors in the selective oxidation of cyclohexane were synthesized through an easily accessible approach. The HPILs were fully examined by different technologies to confirm the chemical structure and the internal space of the nanoreactor for the reaction. The properties of HPILs could be regulated by IL monomer design, such as charge distribution, hydrophilicity, and substrate transfer, which affect the selective oxidation of CH. Fluorescence microscopy, SASX and Contact angles measurements confirmed the advance of mass transfer in different substrate. In the presence of HPILs, transition metal salt catalysts (CoCl2) showed enhanced activity in which the conversion of CH increased from 8.2% to 19.8% in HPIL-C12. The selectivity of the products seemed to be controlled by the HPIL nanoreactor; HPIL-C4 and HPIL-C6 showed a higher selectivity for KA oil, and HPIL-C12 had a high selectivity for AA. In CoCl2/HPIL-C12, the maximum AA selectivity of 72.7% could be obtained under a high conversion of 27.8%. In the kinetic study, the reaction was consisted with first-order kinetics which CoCl2/HPIL-C12 had a lower the activation energy of 29.1 kJ/mol. In the reaction, selective substrate transfer occurred in HPILs, in which CH could freely transfer into the reactor while KA transport was controlled in HPIL-C12. Most importantly, HPILs storing the catalysts could be recovered and reused 7 times without significant decreasing activity. Full measurements of the catalytic system before and after the reaction confirmed the stability of the catalyst/nanoreactor. In addition, the participating HPILs promote the generation of radicals that show a new signal at g = 2.003 in the EPR spectra. Furthermore, the theoretical model for the hollow structure of HPILs was established to support the experimental results and to predict the catalytic performance inside HPIL nanoreactor in terms of parameters that could be easily controlled by IL monomer design. Overall, this strategy offers a new process for oxidation and could be introduced in different systems. The nanoreactor with the IL monomer could store the metal salts and be easily designed, giving it possible to reuse and improve the activity, which could widely extend to other reactions as desired. coredata.dc:description: Hollow structure nanoreactors take advantage of catalyst loading and enhanced activity by shell construction. In this work, functionalized poly(ionic liquid)s (PILs) with hollow spherical structures were synthesized by polymerization- and quaternization-based approaches. These hollow structure PILs (HPILs) could be controllable designed from IL monomer easily, giving HPILs various properties. In the subsequent selective oxidation of cyclohexane, the HPILs acting as nanoreactors could efficiently improve the activity of metal salt catalysts (CoCl2) and displayed adjustable selectivity for cyclohexanone, cyclohexanol (KA) or adipic acid (AA) by different types of HPILs. In kinetic study, it follows first-order reaction kinetics which CoCl2/HPIL-C12 had a lower the activation energy of 29.1 kJ/mol. Importantly, these nanoreactors storing the catalysts could be recovered and reused more than 7 times without significant loss of activity. A theoretical model for the hollow spherical reactor was further established to support the advance of the HPILs reactor, which could also help to predict reaction process in other core-shell catalytic system. Due to controlled substrate transfer and enhanced radical generation in HPILs, the reaction process could be adjusted to enhance the conversion of cyclohexane and selective oxidation to AA.
coredata.dc:title: Poly(ionic liquid)s hollow spheres nanoreactor for enhanced cyclohexane catalytic oxidation
